body: Where in Devise is `timedout` being used? I searched through the codebase and couldn't find any reference to it.

In the FailureApp class, the redirect (https://github.com/plataformatec/devise/blob/master/lib/devise/failure_app.rb#L58-L59) and redirect_url (https://github.com/plataformatec/devise/blob/master/lib/devise/failure_app.rb#L91) methods reference :timedout.

Does this make sense? We aren't able to point to anything else in our app that would cause the tests to  break after this commit.

The tests we're doing are really simple. Here's an example:

```
require 'spec_helper'

describe 'feedback page' do
  before do
    @admin = FactoryGirl.create(:admin_user)
    @feedback = FactoryGirl.create(:feedback)
    visit '/admin/'
    fill_in 'admin_user_email', with: @admin.email
    fill_in 'admin_user_password', with: @admin.password
    click_button 'Login'
    visit '/admin/feedbacks'
  end

  it 'should display a feedback' do
    expect(page).to have_content(@feedback.description)
  end
end
```

Turns out this [https://github.com/activeadmin/activeadmin/issues/512#issuecomment-10413920] fixed my issue. Though it's a mystery why https://github.com/activeadmin/activeadmin/commit/1d73c0a267510543e46d2174c8cb627e6a84190a would cause it to happen.

Hey guys, we recently updated AA and are seeing `
true
` rendered in our flash when the session times out. To see it you can just add a simple method in your your class: ``` class AdminUser devise :timeoutable def timeout_in 5.seconds end end ``` Login, wait 5 seconds, then click to another page and you'll get this: ![timeout](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/172409/4747053/95e3b590-5a55-11e4-9da9-6c25a3288387.png) The line where this is set is in devise right here: https://github.com/plataformatec/devise/blob/master/lib/devise/failure_app.rb#L92 To resolve it we'll just have to use something like `flash.to_hash.except('timedout')` where we build the flash in `ActiveAdmin::Views::Bages::Base#build_flashes` (https://github.com/activeadmin/activeadmin/blob/master/lib/active_admin/views/pages/base.rb#L78-L80)
I missed a spot here, too: https://github.com/activeadmin/activeadmin/blob/master/app/views/layouts/active_admin_logged_out.html.erb#L23
It really is unfortunate that devise uses the flash in this way, lots of people working around this issue: https://github.com/plataformatec/devise/issues/1777

I my opinion we should not write code that fixes a devise problem. This feels bad:

``` ruby
falsh.except!(:timedout).each do |type, message|
  # ...
end
```

Whats happen if `cancan` do the same? `except!(:timedout, :cancan_foo, :pundit_bar)`, that can't be a solution.

@josevalim propose to check to check that the value `respond_to?(:to_str)`. That could be a way.

Or we build a `display_flash_messages` helper that can be configured to except keys.

> Or we build a `display_flash_messages` helper that can be configured to except keys.

There used to be one, but I removed it in 1d73c0a267510543e46d2174c8cb627e6a84190a. I could have sworn at the time that I searched through the Devise codebase and couldn't find a reference to `timedout`. I guess that day the Github search UI wasn't working properly.

Devise used `timeout` in the [FailureApp](https://github.com/plataformatec/devise/blob/master/lib/devise/failure_app.rb#L56).

The old `active_admin_flash_messages` looks like a Devise bug fix. We should fix bugs of dependencies.

In my mind, I have this:

``` ruby
def render_flash_messages(&block)
  flash.to_hash.except(namespace.flash_keys_to_except).each(&block)
end

# or

def flash_messages
  @flash_messages ||= flash.to_hash.except(namespace.flash_keys_to_except)
end

# Set flash message keys that shouldn't show in ActiveAdmin
# `:timeout` is used by Devise, see #3316 for details.
config.flash_keys_to_except = [:timeout]

# or

# Set flash message keys that shouldn't show in ActiveAdmin
config.flash_keys_to_except = []
## and the developer can configure it when he need that
```

This is more generic that a static `expect(:timeout)`.

issue.title: Weird flash message with Timeoutable

repository.name: devise
repository.description: Flexible authentication solution for Rails with Warden.

issue.body:
## Environment - Ruby 3.3.4 - Rails 7.2.1 - Devise 4.9.4 ## Current behavior When using `timeoutable`, a time out results in two messages being assigned to flash, an alert (expected) and a message of type `"timedout"` with value `true` (unexpected). ## Expected behavior That the Flash will only contain notices and alerts. I realise this has been raised previously (multiple times, see below) and the most prominent one was marked as "resolved" (https://github.com/heartcombo/devise/pull/1993) but I wonder if, 10-15 years later, we can revisit the decision since it's still tripping people up? The [documentation](https://api.rubyonrails.org/v7.2.1/classes/ActionDispatch/Flash.html) refers to "notices and alerts" and specifically calls out that the flash is automatically exposed to the template. Tutorials ([RubyGuides](https://www.rubyguides.com/2019/11/rails-flash-messages/), [Rapid Ruby](https://rapidruby.com/lessons/22-flash-messages-with-hotwire), [Reinteractive](https://reinteractive.com/articles/how-to-create-flash-messages-in-Rails-7) [and](https://www.hotrails.dev/turbo-rails/flash-messages-hotwire) [many](https://bootrails.com/blog/how-to-use-rails-flash-messages/) [more](https://dev.to/bdavidxyz/rails-flash-messages-and-ux-3kep)) almost always assume the Flash will only contain user facing messages that have been exposed to the template. It seems like a pretty solid convention. For over a decade, and to this day, people have been: - asking about it on Stackoverflow ([1](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/12256203/devise-timedout-error-showing-true), [2](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27538622/message-true-flashes-on-main-page-after-session-timeout), [3](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/31600512/devise-3-5-x-on-rails-4-2-x-timeout-prints-true-underneath-timeout-flash-messa)) - raising issues in this repo ([1](https://github.com/heartcombo/devise/issues/193), [2](https://github.com/heartcombo/devise/issues/219), [3](https://github.com/heartcombo/devise/issues/1777), [4](https://github.com/heartcombo/devise/issues/2417), [5](https://github.com/heartcombo/devise/issues/2787)) - discussing it and working around it in other repos ([Active Admin](https://github.com/activeadmin/activeadmin/issues/3316), [The Odin Project](https://github.com/TheOdinProject/theodinproject/pull/4564) [and](https://github.com/leonid-shevtsov/unobtrusive_flash) [many](https://github.com/ministryofjustice/Claim-for-Crown-Court-Defence/pull/5203) [more](https://github.com/tramlinehq/tramline/pull/140)), with many references to this as a bug in Devise ## Workaround In case the decision stands and someone else stumbles across this in the future and isn't helped by the terse message in the readme (https://github.com/heartcombo/devise/pull/1993), I've worked around it by skipping messages of type "timedout" (`next if type == "timedout"`). Another suggestion is to check if the message/value is a string (`next unless message.is_a? String`). Here is that line with a bit more context from my view partial in case it's helpful: ```rb # app/views/shared/_flash_messages.html.erb <% if flash.any? %>
<% flash.each do |type, message| %> <% next if type == "timedout" %>
<%= "#{type.capitalize}" %> <%= message %>
<% end %>
<% end %> ```
